sentence.text: Drug Label for drug brand DYAZIDE, containing hydrochlorothiazide and triamterene.

mmtx.phraseText: Drug Label for drug brand DYAZIDE,
Drug Label for drug brand DYAZIDE,

sentence.text: DYAZIDE should not be given to patients receiving other potassium-sparing agents such as spironolactone, amiloride, or other formulations containing triamterene.

mmtx.phraseText: other potassium-sparing agents such as spironolactone,
other potassium-sparing agents such as spironolactone,
other potassium-sparing agents such as spironolactone,

sentence.text: Concomitant potassium-containing salt substitutes should also not be used.

ellipsisSentence.text: DYAZIDE should not be given to patients receiving other potassium-sparing agents such as spironolactone, amiloride, or other formulations containing triamterene.

sentence.text: Potassium supplementation should not be used with DYAZIDE except in severe cases of hypokalemia.
Such concomitant therapy can be associated with rapid increases in serum potassium levels.

ellipsisSentence.text: Potassium supplementation should not be used with DYAZIDE except in severe cases of hypokalemia.
Potassium supplementation should not be used with DYAZIDE except in severe cases of hypokalemia.

sentence.text: If potassium supplementation is used, careful monitoring of the serum potassium level is necessary.

ellipsisSentence.text: Potassium supplementation should not be used with DYAZIDE except in severe cases of hypokalemia.

middleSentence.text: Such concomitant therapy can be associated with rapid increases in serum potassium levels.

sentence.text: DYAZIDE should not be used in patients with preexisting elevated serum potassium.
Hyperkalemia: Abnormal elevation of serum potassium levels (greater than or equal to 5.5 mEq/liter) can occur with all potassium-sparing diuretic combinations, including DYAZIDE.

mmtx.phraseText: occur with all potassium-sparing diuretic combinations,
Abnormal elevation of serum potassium levels

sentence.text: Since uncorrected hyperkalemia may be fatal, serum potassium levels must be monitored at frequent intervals especially in patients first receiving DYAZIDE, when dosages are changed or with any illness that may influence renal function.
If hyperkalemia is present, DYAZIDE should be discontinued immediately and a thiazide alone should be substituted.
If the serum potassium exceeds 6.5 mEq/liter more vigorous therapy is required.

These include the intravenous administration of calcium chloride solution, sodium bicarbonate solution, and/or the oral or parenteral administration of glucose with a rapid-acting insulin preparation.

mmtx.phraseText: the intravenous administration of calcium chloride solution,

sentence.text: The renal clearances of hydrochlorothiazide and the pharmacologically active metabolite of triamterene, the sulfate ester of hydroxytriamterene, have been shown to be reduced and the plasma levels increased following administration of DYAZIDE to elderly patients and patients with impaired renal function.

mmtx.phraseText: the pharmacologically active metabolite of triamterene,

sentence.text: Accordingly, serum electrolytes must be frequently monitored if DYAZIDE is used in diabetic patients.
If DYAZIDE is employed, frequent evaluations of acid/base balance and serum electrolytes are necessary.
Hydrochlorothiazide, a sulfonamide, can cause an idiosyncratic reaction, resulting in acute transient myopia and acute angle-closure glaucoma.
Caution should be exercised when administering DYAZIDE to patients with diabetes, since thiazides may cause hyperglycemia, glycosuria, and alter insulin requirements in diabetes.
Hypokalemia is uncommon with DYAZIDE, but, should it develop, corrective measures should be taken such as potassium supplementation or increased intake of potassium-rich foods.
Institute such measures cautiously with frequent determinations of serum potassium levels, especially in patients receiving digitalis or with a history of cardiac arrhythmias.

antecedentSentence.Text: Hypokalemia is uncommon with DYAZIDE, but, should it develop, corrective measures should be taken such as potassium supplementation or increased intake of potassium-rich foods.
Hypokalemia is uncommon with DYAZIDE, but, should it develop, corrective measures should be taken such as potassium supplementation or increased intake of potassium-rich foods.

sentence.text: If serious hypokalemia (serum potassium less than 3.0 mEq/L) is demonstrated by repeat serum potassium determinations, DYAZIDE should be discontinued and potassium chloride supplementation initiated.

mmtx.phraseText: demonstrated by repeat serum potassium determinations,

sentence.text: Electrolyte imbalance, often encountered in such conditions as heart failure, renal disease or cirrhosis of the liver, may also be aggravated by diuretics and should be considered during therapy with DYAZIDE when using high doses for prolonged periods or in patients on a salt-restricted diet.
If hypokalemia should develop, corrective measures should be taken such as potassium supplementation or increased dietary intake of potassium-rich foods.

mmtx.phraseText: increased dietary intake of potassium-rich foods.

sentence.text: Discontinue corrective measures for hypokalemia immediately if laboratory determinations reveal an abnormal elevation of serum potassium.

mmtx.phraseText: an abnormal elevation of serum potassium.

sentence.text: Discontinue DYAZIDE and substitute a thiazide diuretic alone until potassium levels return to normal.
DYAZIDE may produce an elevated blood urea nitrogen level, creatinine level or both.

mmtx.phraseText: an elevated blood urea nitrogen level,

sentence.text: Calcium excretion is decreased by thiazides.
Potassium-sparing agents should be used with caution in conjunction with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors due to an increased risk of hyperkalemia.

mmtx.phraseText: in conjunction with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors

sentence.text: Oral Hypoglycemic Drugs
Concurrent use with chlorpropamide may increase the risk of severe hyponatremia.
A possible interaction resulting in acute renal failure has been reported in a few patients on DYAZIDE when treated with indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agent.
Caution is advised in administering nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents with DYAZIDE.

mmtx.phraseText: advised in administering nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents

sentence.text: Lithium generally should not be given with diuretics because they reduce its renal clearance and increase the risk of lithium toxicity.
Read circulars for lithium preparations before use of such concomitant therapy with DYAZIDE.
Thiazides have been shown to decrease arterial responsiveness to norepinephrine (an effect attributed to loss of sodium).

Thiazides have also been shown to increase the paralyzing effect of nondepolarizing muscle relaxants such as tubocurarine (an effect attributed to potassium loss), consequently caution should be observed in patients undergoing surgery.

mmtx.phraseText: the paralyzing effect of nondepolarizing muscle relaxants

sentence.text: Concurrent use of hydrochlorothiazide with amphotericin B or corticosteroids or corticotropin (ACTH) may intensify electrolyte imbalance, particularly hypokalemia, although the presence of triamterene minimizes the hypokalemic effect.
Thiazides may add to or potentiate the action of other antihypertensive drugs.

mmtx.phraseText: the action of other antihypertensive drugs.

sentence.text: The effect of oral anticoagulants may be decreased when used concurrently with hydrochlorothiazide, dosage adjustments may be necessary.
DYAZIDE may raise the level of blood uric acid, dosage adjustments of antigout medication may be necessary to control hyperuricemia and gout.

The following agents given together with triamterene may promote serum potassium accumulation and possibly result in hyperkalemia because of the potassium-sparing nature of triamterene, especially in patients with renal insufficiency: blood from blood bank (may contain up to 30 mEq of potassium per liter of plasma or up to 65 mEq per liter of whole blood when stored for more than 10 days), low-salt milk (may contain up to 60 mEq of potassium per liter), potassium-containing medications (such as parenteral penicillin G potassium), salt substitutes (most contain substantial amounts of potassium).

mmtx.phraseText: such as parenteral penicillin G potassium

sentence.text: Exchange resins, such as sodium polystyrene sulfonate, whether administered orally or rectally, reduce serum potassium levels by sodium replacement of the potassium, fluid retention may occur in some patients because of the increased sodium intake.

mmtx.phraseText: serum potassium levels by sodium replacement of the potassium,
serum potassium levels by sodium replacement of the potassium,
because of the increased sodium intake.

sentence.text: Chronic or overuse of laxatives may reduce serum potassium levels by promoting excessive potassium loss from the intestinal tract, laxatives may interfere with the potassium-retaining effects of triamterene.

mmtx.phraseText: interfere with the potassium-retaining effects of triamterene.

sentence.text: The effectiveness of methenamine may be decreased when used concurrently with hydrochlorothiazide because of alkalinization of the urine.
Triamterene and quinidine have similar fluorescence spectra, thus, DYAZIDE will interfere with the fluorescent measurement of quinidine.

mmtx.phraseText: interfere with the fluorescent measurement of quinidine.

sentence.text: Long-term studies have not been conducted with DYAZIDE (the triamterene/hydrochlorothiazide combination), or with triamterene alone.

On a body-weight basis, these doses are 600 times (in mice) and 100 times (in rats) the Maximum Recommended Human Dose (MRHD) for the hydrochlorothiazide component of DYAZIDE at 50 mg/day (or 1.0 mg/kg/day based on 50 kg individuals).
Studies of the mutagenic potential of DYAZIDE (the triamterene/hydrochlorothiazide combination), or of triamterene alone have not been performed.

mmtx.phraseText: Studies of the mutagenic potential of DYAZIDE

sentence.text: Studies of the effects of DYAZIDE (the triamterene/hydrochlorothiazide combination), or of triamterene alone on animal reproductive function have not been conducted.

mmtx.phraseText: Studies of the effects of DYAZIDE

sentence.text: However, a One Generation Study in the rat approximated composition of DYAZIDE by using a 1:1 ratio of triamterene to hydrochlorothiazide (30:30 mg/kg/day), there was no evidence of teratogenicity at those doses which were, on a body-weight basis, 15 and 30 times, respectively, the MRHD, and on the basis of body-surface area, 3.1 and 6.2 times, respectively, the MRHD.

mmtx.phraseText: and on the basis of body-surface area,
a One Generation Study in the rat approximated composition of DYAZIDE

sentence.text: Reproduction studies have been performed in rats at doses as high as 20 times the MRHD on the basis of body-weight, and 6 times the human dose on the basis of body-surface area without evidence of harm to the fetus due to triamterene.

mmtx.phraseText: the human dose on the basis of body-surface area
the MRHD on the basis of body-weight,

sentence.text: Thiazides and triamterene have been shown to cross the placental barrier and appear in cord blood.
The use of thiazides and triamterene in pregnant women requires that the anticipated benefit be weighed against possible hazards to the fetus.
Thiazides and triamterene in combination have not been studied in nursing mothers.
Thiazides are excreted in human breast milk.
If use of the combination drug product is deemed essential, the patient should stop nursing.

mmtx.phraseText: use of the combination drug product
use of the combination drug product
